awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: An Algebraic Approach to Secure Multilinear Maps for Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is an interdisciplinary collaboration between mathematicians and computer scientists in an intensive focused research effort to solve a central challenge in cryptography, namely constructing a family of secure and efficient algebraic multilinear maps.  Multilinear maps have remarkable applications in cryptography, such as multiuser non-interactive key-exchange, general functional encryption, fully-homomorphic encryption, and indistinguishability obfuscation. The results of the project are expected to enable a new age of cryptographic systems and open new directions in the field.  The project will train graduate students and postdoctoral associates through involvement in deep modern mathematics research with applications in computer science.

The first candidate multilinear maps are inefficient in practice, and have been shown to be insecure for some of the desired applications. This project takes a very different approach from earlier ones. The starting point is the observation that there already exist many natural multilinear maps in arithmetic geometry, arising naturally from the cohomology of arithmetic varieties and motives, and from K-theory. They give a richer class of objects than elliptic curves over finite fields, whose groups of points are widely used in practice for cryptographic key exchange and public-key encryption. The challenge is to find such algebraic structures for which the multilinear maps can be efficiently computed, and for which the associated cryptographic problems (e.g., discrete logarithm problems) are expected to be hard.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit associated with the project outcome includes a series of publications on cryptography and the related mathematics, including work that gives a greater understanding of the security of some types of lattice-based cryptography, a proposal for how to construct a quantum money system using the mathematics of quaternion algebras, modular forms, and elliptic curves, a proposal for a system to do multiparty non-interactive Key Exchange using elliptic curves, and work that sheds light on the question of whether such a system can be constructed.


The broader impacts of the work include training and mentoring of postdocoral researchers and graduate students, dissemination of knowledge through lectures (technical lectures in the research area, lectures for general mathematical audiences, lectures for the general public, and lectures for students and other early career mathematicians), and organization of a number of conferences, seminars, working groups, and workshops that help to train early career mathematicians, to disseminate information on work in the field, and to form interdisciplinary communities in mathematics and computer science to work on questions that involve both cryptography and mathematics. Broader impacts also include the impact of essays written by the Principal Investigator I that have been cited (in the Notices of the American Mathematical Society) as good sources to read to help "combat discrimination and prejudice".
